Mea culpa! 
I've posted the topic on saturday morning. Meanwhile, after pla=
ying a
little bit with the mass flux and pressure, I recognized that the
(u=
nderestimated) back diffusion plays an important role at low mass
fluxes or=
 higher pressures and the results are reasonable. 

Thanks for your reply!
=

Best regards

Holger D.

--- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, "E David Huckaby"=

<e.david.huckaby@...> wrote:
>
>  
> The initial mass fraction of the spec=
ies at z =3D 0, will in general not
> be the same as 
> the specified mass =
fraction for the flame models because the boundary
> condition for species =

> is a specified flux, F_k condition as opposed to specified mass
> fracti=
on. This flux is equal to the product 
> of the specified species mass frac=
tion, Y_k and the specified mass
> flux, mdot.  The mass fraction
> at the =
burner or inlet, Y_k[0], will in general be different than one
> specified =
due to diffusive fluxes
> to or from the inlet.
>  
> The equation is discr=
etized as:
> F_k =3D mdot Y_k =3D  rho[0] * u[0] * Y_k[0] - D_k (Y_k[1] - Y=
_k[0])/(z[1]
> - z[0])
>  
>  
> hope this helps
> Dave H.
>  
> 
> 
> >>> =
holger.doerr@... 10/21/2006 7:36 AM >>>
> 
> Hello,
> running the flame1.py=
 burner stabilized flame simulation I recognized
> that the concentration o=
f H2O (water) is at z=3D0 about a third of the
> final concentration, a  li=
ttle depending on the pressure. From my
> knowledge of mass balancing the i=
nitial concentration must be 0 for
> water, and the concentrations at z=3D0=
 unequal to zero should be only
> those of the educts hydrogen, oxygen and =
the inertial gas argon. 
> I've used the unaltered script flame1.py of cant=
era-1.6.0, varied only
> the pressure within 0.03-1 atm. A similar behaviou=
r is observable for
> CK II running premixed H2-O2-Ar flames or C2H2-O2-fla=
mes, but this is
> no CK II group, but interesting for me (some form of oo-=
inheritance?-).
> 
> Textbooks about combustion (Warnatz et al.) show graph=
s with initial
> water concentrations of zero. 
> Is something wrong in my =
interpretation of the results in flame1.csv? 
> 
> Best regards from German=
y
> 
> Holger
